text: When I feel sudden fear rising, I notice it as a false alarm and breathe slowly to calm my body.
During moments of physical intensity, I recognize the sensations as normal body responses, not real danger.
When my heart starts racing, I pause and breathe deeply instead of letting fear take over.
I let physical symptoms like chest pain or dizziness convince me that something dangerous is happening.
When I sense the pattern starting—fear, physical rush, panic—I interrupt it early by staying still and breathing.
I recognize when my mind is catastrophizing body sensations, and I choose a calmer interpretation instead.
When I feel the urge to escape or avoid a situation, I notice the fear and choose to stay present instead.
I let worry about having another panic attack control my choices and limit my daily activities.
When I notice shortness of breath or dizziness, I breathe slowly and ground myself instead of panicking.
I see when my mind is interpreting normal body sensations as threats, and I choose to observe them without reacting.
When I feel the pull to worry about losing control, I notice the thought and let it pass without engaging with it.
I let fear of going crazy or losing control drive me into avoidance or escape behaviors.
When I sense the early warning signs of panic, I prepare my breathing and stay grounded instead of escalating the fear.
I recognize when my body is reacting to a false alarm, and I respond with calm instead of urgency.
When I feel sudden fear without a clear reason, I notice it as the pattern and breathe through it instead of fighting it.
I let panic symptoms feel like emergencies that require immediate escape or medical attention.
When I notice the cycle of fear feeding physical symptoms, I interrupt it by slowing my breathing and staying present.
I see when my mind is creating worst-case scenarios about my body, and I choose a simpler, more realistic view.
When I feel the urge to check my body for symptoms, I notice the pattern and redirect my attention outward instead.
I let fear of panic attacks prevent me from entering situations or doing things I want to do.
